awd_titl_txt: Harnessing the Power of Weak Bonds: Cleavage of N-O Bonds as Key Steps in Domino and Rearrangement Reactions of Functionalized Hydroxylamines
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor László Kürti of Rice University is studying the design and development of new streamlined methods for the production of nitrogen-containing molecules. These new methods offer potentially greener and more economical alternatives for manufacturing intermediates and target molecules for numerous applications ranging from agriculture, medicine, molecular electronics all the way to 21st century materials. The new molecular transformations exploit weak nitrogen-oxygen (N–O) bonds, which when ruptured, initiate carefully orchestrated sequences of chemical reactions, also known as domino reactions. The domino processes cause the skeletons of the original molecules to rearrange into completely new ones. These types of molecular rearrangement reactions are among the most efficient and atom-economical processes known to chemistry. Prof. Kürti has been a faculty sponsor of the Rice University chapter of Fun with Chemistry, an outreach program that has the short-term goal of establishing a robust Houston-area satellite program. The long-term goal is to initiate similar satellite programs in other major Texas metropolitan areas. This outreach program provides K-12 students in Texas with the opportunity to participate in experimental-learning through captivating science experiments. Curiosity for science is piqued through fun demonstrations that highlight important educational lessons by utilizing a variety of role models. In particular, this educational program strives to reach traditionally underrepresented minorities and highlight that anyone can be a scientist! The ultimate goal of the program is to inspire young students to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM)-fields.

Professor Kürti’s research group will be exploring four fundamentally new domino reaction strategies to produce small-ring- and aromatic heterocycles. The common theme of these transformations is the nature of the activation of the substrates or intermediates: by a scission of their weak N–O bonds. Depending on the strategy, this N–O bond cleavage either triggers or drives the particular transformation, which include new ring-contractions and [3,3]-sigmatropic rearrangements. Making highly-substituted nitrogen-containing molecules is a long-standing challenge in synthetic organic chemistry. The proposed project aims to address this challenge: the driving force offered by cleaving N–O bonds enables the operationally simple construction of numerous challenging nitrogen-containing molecules, including ones currently unknown to chemistry. The proposed research promises to offer new, reliable, transition metal-free synthetic methods as alternatives to traditional approaches, and is expected to have impact on chemists in academic, governmental and industrial laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project significantly advanced the field of synthetic organic chemistry by exploring and harnessing the unique reactivities of the N−O bond. The research aimed to develop novel, operationally simple, and environmentally benign methods for synthesizing small- and medium-sized heterocyclic ring systems. A major focus was placed on creating new domino and rearrangement reactions involving functionalized hydroxylamine derivatives.

Major Accomplishments

Novel Reactivities & Advances in Sustainable/Efficient Synthetic Strategies

The project uncovered several new reactivities of the N−O bond, leading to the development of innovative synthetic methods:

  • Synthesis of O-Vinyl Hydroxylamines as Ring-Annulation Reagents: A scalable method was developed for synthesizing O-vinyl hydroxylamines, both singly N-protected and N-unprotected. These compounds were stable in solution and, upon N-vinylation/arylation, underwent [3,3]-sigmatropic rearrangements, leading to the synthesis of various N-heterocycles, including pyrroles, indoles, and aza-indoles. This work significantly expanded the chemical space accessible through N−O bond manipulation, providing a broader toolbox of mechanistically well-understood and predictable reactions that contribute to the field of organic synthesis.
  • Ring-Closure Reactions for Lactam Synthesis: A halonium-ion initiated ring-closure method was established for synthesizing N-alkoxy-alpha-halogenated beta lactams. This method was further extended to produce larger lactams, highlighting its potential for generating a wide range of biologically relevant structures. The use of inexpensive and readily available starting materials, combined with the avoidance of costly late transition metal catalysts, underscores the project's impact on promoting greener and more cost-effective synthetic methodologies.
  • Development of Novel Beta-Lactam Chemistry: The project explored the synthesis and reactivity of N-alkoxy-alpha-halogenated beta lactams. These novel beta-lactam intermediates proved highly versatile, undergoing transformations such as radical allylation and aza-quasi-Favorskii rearrangement to yield complex nitrogen-containing heterocycles like aziridines.
  • Cascade Reactions for Pyridine Synthesis: A novel synthetic route was devised for preparing substituted pyridines through a multi-step cascade reaction involving ring-dibrominated O-cyclopropyl hydroxylamines and ketones. This method demonstrated the feasibility of creating complex heterocyclic structures from simple starting materials, offering a practical solution for synthesizing biologically active compounds. These operationally simple reactions are accessible to researchers in a wide range of academic and industrial laboratories, even those with limited synthesis experience.
  • Catalytic Nitrenium Ion Generation and Cyclization: The catalytic generation of stabilized nitrenium ions was demonstrated, facilitating the formation of 2-quinolones through intramolecular electrophilic aromatic substitution. This work opened new possibilities for synthesizing unique 2-quinolone derivatives, which are important substructures in medicinal chemistry. This method provides a more environmentally benign and less toxic alternative to traditional approaches, advancing the field of green chemistry.
  • Total Synthesis of Saccardianine A: Significant progress was made towards the total synthesis of the natural product Saccardianine A. By optimizing key steps, including an oxime C-allylation and an intramolecular nitrone-olefin [3+2]-cycloaddition, the team successfully optimized two-thirds of the synthetic sequence, bringing the total synthesis of this natural product within reach.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

This research has significantly advanced the field of organic synthesis by expanding the toolbox of mechanistically well-understood and predictable rearrangements and domino reactions. The ability to efficiently combine inexpensive reagents and simple substrates to produce products with increased molecular complexity has led to the emergence of structurally unique N-containing compounds. These compounds hold promise as valuable intermediates in the synthesis of natural products, ligands, catalysts, functional materials, drug leads, and agrochemicals.

Moreover, the research is expected to have a broad societal impact by providing greener and more cost-effective access to valuable organic molecules, including medicines and agrochemicals. The operational simplicity of the developed reactions makes them accessible to a wide range of researchers, from academic labs to industrial settings, promoting the widespread adoption of these sustainable methodologies.

Training and Professional Development

The project provided extensive training opportunities for postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates. Trainees were involved in all aspects of the research, from experimental design and execution to data analysis and manuscript preparation. This hands-on experience was invaluable in preparing them for future careers in academia and industry.

Conclusion

This NSF-funded project has made significant contributions to synthetic organic chemistry by developing novel methods for exploiting N−O bonds and creating complex molecular structures. The sustainable and efficient synthetic strategies developed will have broad applications in pharmaceuticals and other industries. The project's intellectual merit and broader impacts ensure that these advancements will continue to influence the field and society for years to come.
